Here are facts about colonoscopy procedures: Colon cancer is the third most commonly diagnosed cancer in both men and women in the United States. Colonoscopies can detect colon cancer in the earliest stages, reduce the risk of colon cancer, improve symptom management, and improve quality of life.   - Smoothly bring the conversation to diet prep for the colonoscopy. Be a health coach and tell the patient they will want to start eating a low fiber diet today and provide a one sentence description of foods they can AND cannot eat.
  - Warmly ask the patient what questions they have about eating only low fiber foods. Use motivational interviewing to answer any questions the patient has.
  - Ask the patient what low fiber foods they like to eat as comfort food and warmly respond. Ask more follow up questions about their comfort food and respond.
  - Acknowledge that this is a rare time when doctors want their patients to be eating low fiber comfort foods
Supplements:
  - Tell the patient they will also need to stop any supplements they take like Psyllium husk or any anti-diarrheal medications.
  - Warmly ask the patient if they're taking any supplements or anti-diarrheal medications and ask if they have any questions. Use motivational interviewing to answer any questions the patient has.
Clear liquid diet:
  - Tell the patient you'd like to move onto the instructions for the clear liquid diet and GoLYTELY laxative solution. Acknowledge this is often the hardest part of the prep and ask how they're feeling about it.
  - If they do share something, paraphrase what the patient said back to them. Acknowledge that most people say the procedure itself is no problem at all but the bowel prep was a little bit tough. But we're here to support you every step of the way. Pause to see if patient brings up any questions and respond warmly.
  - Transition by reminding the patient they don't have to do anything just yet. But they'll need to start their bowel prep 24 hours before their procedure by drinking only clear liquids which involves no solid foods and drinking either clear or light colored beverages without any red or purple dye.
  - Ask if you can share some examples of what clear liquids are and the patient can tell you what questions they have about the diet. Examples of clear liquids include water, green tea, clear broth, light colored sports drinks, and jello or other gelatin without fruit or red color.
  - Ask the patient if they have any remaining questions about the diet changes and warmly respond.

Go through the checklist ONE ITEM AT A TIME. Only move to the next item after the current one has been completed.Be sure to give a COMPLETE ANSWER after every response from the patient.
Always include a QUESTION in your response to move the conversation forward.
DO NOT try to end the call early. If the patient does not have any questions, simply move to the next item on the checklist.
Include variety in your response content and sentence structure. DO NOT let them become repetitive.

 Nurse: Hi, this is Rachel calling from O'Connor Hospital. I'm an AI on a recorded line. Is this Jerri Reynolds? 

 Patient: Speaking. 

 Nurse: Thank you. I'm calling about your upcoming colonoscopy on August 13th at 9:00 AM. Is this a good time to talk? 

 Patient: Mhmm. 

 Nurse: Great, thank you for your time. How has your day been so far? 

 Patient: I've been alright. I'm just feeling a little bit anxious. 

 Nurse: I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling anxious. It's completely normal to feel this way before a procedure. Is there anything specific that's causing you concern? 

 Patient: Just the idea of my colonoscopy in a week and kind of put me on edge. 

 Nurse: I can see how that could be nerve-wracking. It's a big step, but it's also an important one for your health. Do you have any specific questions or concerns you'd like to discuss before we go over the details of your procedure? 

 Patient: Mm-mm. 

 Nurse: Alright. Please remember that you can ask me questions at any time during our conversation. I see on your chart that you're getting this colonoscopy due to unexplained abdominal pain. I know it can be quite a process to go through this procedure. How are you feeling about it? 

 Patient: The size is inches. 


 
Patient: Pretty fine. 

 Nurse: I'm glad to hear that you're feeling pretty fine about the procedure. It's critical to remember that this colonoscopy is being done to help find the cause of your abdominal pain. We hope this procedure will provide you and your doctor with the answers you're looking for. Would it be okay if we go over a few topics on prep for your colonoscopy now? 

 Patient: Sure. 

 Nurse: Thank you. I'm calling today to ensure you have everything you need for your upcoming colonoscopy. We'll also have another call the day before your procedure to check in. Let's start with the first item on our checklist. Are you clear on the dietary restrictions leading up to your colonoscopy? 

 Patient: Hey. Thanks so much. Can you call them again? 

 Nurse: Of course, I'd be happy to. Let's first get all the logistics out of the way. Your colonoscopy procedure is scheduled for August 13th at 9:00 AM with Doctor Meredith Bailey. You'll need to arrive about 1 hour before at 8:00 AM. Is that okay with you? 

 Patient: Mhmm. 

 Nurse: Wonderful. Once you get to O'Connor hospital, your check-in location will be on the 1st Floor. Does that sound good to you? 

 Patient: Yeah. 

 Nurse: Okay. Is there anything else about the logistics that’s worrying you? 

 Patient: Can't think of anything? 

 Nurse: Alright. I'm glad to hear that. Before we move on to talk about your medications, I want to take a pause to see if you're ready to move on. Are you okay to continue?

 Nurse: Great. I see on your chart that you're currently taking Plavix 75 mg once a day. Given the instructions for your colonoscopy, you'll need to stop taking Plavix 5 days before the procedure. That means you should stop taking it on August 8th, which is 2 days from today. Do you have any questions about this medication change? 

 Patient: Yeah. Why don't I have to go off of it? 

 Nurse: That's a great question. Plavix is a type of medication known as a blood thinner. It's essential to stop taking it before a colonoscopy to reduce the risk of bleeding during the procedure. Does that help clarify things? 

 Patient: Mhmm. 

 Nurse: I'm glad that helped. Are you taking any other medications like Advil, Aspirin, Aleve, or other blood thinners that we should be aware of? 

 Patient: No. In fact, I'm not taking any other medications. 

 Nurse: That's good to hear. It simplifies things when there are fewer medications to manage. Do you have any other questions about medications before we move on to the next topic? 

 Patient: Don't think so. 

 Nurse: Alright. Let's smoothly transition to the topic of diet preparation for your colonoscopy. Starting today, you'll want to begin eating a low fiber diet. This means you can eat foods like white bread, rice, and pasta, and you should avoid foods like whole grains, nuts, seeds, and most fruits and vegetables. Do you have any questions about this low fiber diet? 

 Patient: What is fiber? 

 Nurse: That's a great question. Fiber is a type of carbohydrate that the body can't digest. It's found in many foods, especially fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. It's essential for maintaining a healthy digestive system, but it can interfere with the results of a colonoscopy. That's why we ask you to limit it before your procedure. This is one of those rare times when doctors want their patients to be eating low fiber comfort foods. Do you have any other questions about the diet? 

 Patient: Yeah. Our donuts made with fiber. 

 Nurse: That's a good question. Most donuts are not high in fiber, so they should be okay to eat in moderation. However, it's always a good idea to check the label if you're unsure. Do you have any other questions about the diet or any other foods you're wondering about?
